explanationSteps.text: Your body has two defense systems working together. The first responds instantly to any threat. The second takes time but remembers enemies forever.
explanationSteps.title: Two Lines of Defense

explanationSteps.text: Physical barriers like skin and mucus stop most invaders. If they get through, patrolling cells called macrophages eat anything that looks foreign.
explanationSteps.title: The First Responders

explanationSteps.text: When threats persist, specialized cells called B cells create antibodies. These Y-shaped proteins stick to specific invaders, marking them for destruction.
explanationSteps.title: The Targeting System

explanationSteps.text: Some cells become memory cells after an infection. They remember the invader's shape for years, letting your body respond faster next time.
explanationSteps.title: Remembering Enemies

explanationSteps.text: A compiler reads your code in stages, like an assembly line. Each stage transforms the code into something closer to what the machine understands.
explanationSteps.title: The Assembly Line

explanationSteps.text: First, lexical analysis breaks your code into tokens - the smallest meaningful units. Keywords, variables, and operators each become distinct pieces.
explanationSteps.title: Breaking into Tokens

explanationSteps.text: The parser takes those tokens and builds a tree structure showing how statements relate. This catches syntax errors like missing parentheses.
explanationSteps.title: Building Structure

explanationSteps.text: Semantic analysis checks if your code makes logical sense. It catches errors like using a string where a number is required.
explanationSteps.title: Checking Meaning

explanationSteps.text: Finally, code generation translates the validated structure into machine instructions the processor can execute directly.
explanationSteps.title: Generating Output

userInput.lessonDescription: Understanding how compilers transform human-readable code into machine-executable instructions through multiple phases of analysis and transformation

explanationSteps.text: Training a neural network means adjusting connection strengths so outputs match desired results. The question is: which connections need adjusting and by how much?
explanationSteps.title: The Adjustment Problem

explanationSteps.text: First, data flows forward through the network, producing a prediction. The difference between prediction and reality is measured as error.
explanationSteps.title: Measuring Mistakes

explanationSteps.text: Error information then flows backward through the network. Each connection learns how much it contributed to the mistake using calculus.
explanationSteps.title: Assigning Blame

explanationSteps.text: Connections that contributed more to errors get larger adjustments. The network gradually improves by making small changes in the direction that reduces error.
explanationSteps.title: Small Steps Downhill

explanationSteps.text: Our brains prefer consistency. When we believe something, finding contradicting evidence feels uncomfortable - like a mental itch we want to scratch away.
explanationSteps.title: The Comfort of Consistency

explanationSteps.text: To avoid discomfort, our brains play tricks. We notice evidence supporting our beliefs and unconsciously filter out or dismiss contradicting evidence.
explanationSteps.title: Selective Attention

explanationSteps.text: This happens automatically, not deliberately. A sports fan genuinely sees more fouls by the opposing team. A political supporter honestly remembers more flaws in opponents.
explanationSteps.title: Unconscious Filtering

explanationSteps.text: Even scientists fall prey to this. That's why research uses blind studies and peer review - external checks against our natural tendency to see what we expect.
explanationSteps.title: Safeguards Help
